Title: Arabian Nights
Quote: A truth once seen by a single mind ends up by imposing itself on the totality of human consciousness.

Title: Aristophanes Two Plays The Birds & The Frogs
Quote: Quickly, bring me a beaker of wine, so that I may wet my mind and say something clever.

Title: Aseop's Fables
Quote: We hang the petty thieves and appoint the great ones to public office.

Title: Atlas Shrugged
Quote: I swear by my life and my love of it that I will never live for the sake of another man, nor ask another man to live for mine.

Title: Don Quixote
Quote: For neither good nor evil can last for ever; and so it follows that as evil has lasted a long time, good must now be close at hand.

Title: East of Eden
Quote: But I have a new love for that glittering instrument, the human soul. It is a lovely and unique thing in the universe. It is always attacked and never destroyed

Title: Euripides
Quote: The fiercest anger of all, the most incurable, Is that which rages in the place of dearest love.

Title: Faust
Quote: All theory is gray, my friend. But forever green is the tree of life.

Title: Grimm's Fairy Tales
Quote: Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster. The world may very likely not always think of them as they think of themselves, but what care they for the world?

Title: Huckleberry Finn
Quote: What’s the use you learning to do right when it’s troublesome to do right and ain’t no trouble to do wrong, and the wages is just the same?

Title: Les Miserables
Quote: And remember, the truth that once was spoken: To love another person is to see the face of God.

Title: Lincoln at the Bardo
Quote: Strange, isn't it? To have dedicated one's life to a certain venture, neglecting other aspects of one's life, only to have that venture, in the end, amount to nothing at all, the products of one's labors ultimately forgotten?

Title: Lord Jim
Quote: My task, which I am trying to achieve is, by the power of the written word, to make you hear, to make you feel--it is, before all, to make you see.

Title: Moby Dick
Quote: As for me, I am tormented with an everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts.

Title: Reminices of a Stock Operator
Quote: If a man didn't make mistakes he'd own the world in a month. But if he didn't profit by his mistakes he wouldn't own a blessed thing.

Title: Shakespeare Plays
Quote: Are you sure/That we are awake? It seems to me/That yet we sleep, we dream

Title: The Aeneid
Quote: The gates of Hell are open night and day; smooth the descent and easy is the way

Title: The Brothers Karamazov
Quote: The mystery of human existence lies not in just staying alive, but in finding something to live for.

Title: The Cherry Orchard & Three Sisters
Quote: Perhaps man has a hundred senses, and when he dies only the five senses that we know perish with him, and the other ninety-five remain alive.

Title: The Count of Monte Cristo
Quote: Moral wounds have this peculiarity - they may be hidden, but they never close; always painful, always ready to bleed when touched, they remain fresh and open in the heart.

Title: The Curious Case of Dr. Jekel & Mr. Hyde
Quote: All human beings, as we meet them, are commingled out of good and evil: and Edward Hyde, alone, in the ranks of mankind, was pure evil.

Title: The Divine Comedy
Quote: O human race, born to fly upward, wherefore at a little wind dost thou so fall?

Title: The Hero with a Thousand Faces
Quote: It is only when a man tames his own demons that he becomes the king of himself if not of the world.

Title: The Iliad
Quote: Any moment might be our last. Everything is more beautiful because we're doomed. You will never be lovelier than you are now. We will never be here again.

Title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
Quote: I profess not to know how women's hearts are wooed and won. To me they have always been matters of riddle and admiration

Title: The Odssey
Quote: A man who has been through bitter experiences and travelled far enjoys even his sufferings after a time

Title: The Oresteia
Quote: Nothing forces us to know what we do not want to know except pain.

Title: The Portrait of an Artist as a Young Man
Quote: The object of the artist is the creation of the beautiful. What the beautiful is is another question.

Title: The Tales of Guy de Maupassant
Quote: Our memory is a more perfect world than the universe: it gives back life to those who no longer exist.

Title: Treasure Island
Quote: Fifteen men on the Dead Man's Chest Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!

Title: Vanity Fair
Quote: Which of us is happy in this world? Which of us has his desire? or, having it, is satisfied?
